Film is good except it does not point out the problem of food as in 1943 the Army had dropped production of the 10 in 1 high calorie ration as a cost cutting measure.  This haunted te Marauders and others thereafter.
another WWII gem from sam fuller post WWII

a band of soldiers (forerunners of today's rangers) must move through enemy territory and secure important points to stop the japanese advance in WW 2.

somewhere in the 70s, and especially the 80s, war movies became much more "realistic" and explored combat more from the subjective psychological perspective. this film however is from the old school - objective, black and white, flag-waving, for love of country and honor old school. as such it works, but i could imagine a much more powerful remake of this film - and surely this is a tale worth retelling.

Truly inspiring perhaps in it's day, Merrill's Marauders doesn't translate well. There are far too many better depictions of war that have been made since. It doesn't even match up to Objective Burma which covered much of the same ground.

Not a bad film at all, although being a Hollywood product it concentrates on the efforts of General Stillwell's Americans rather than General Wingate's British Commonwealth & Empire troops who actually did most of the fighting against the Japanese in Burma. Ty Hardin looked eerily familiiar - sort of a bit like a cross between Jeffery Hunter & Clint Eastwood. Turns out he also played Major Reno in Custer of the West (which is the last film I mistook him for Jeffery Hunter in) and where I'd seen him. Apparently he turned down the Clint Eastwood role in A Fistful of Dollars (fool)!

MERRILLS MARAUDERS qualifies as a testament to the tenacity and the strength of America's fighting men and a story as heroic as anything that ever came out of ancient Greece with its tales of legendary heroes. These flesh & blood heroes here sweated out the worst that the Japanese could deliver and triumphed over incredible odds. Indeed, these G.I.s were often outnumbered and outgunned but they won in the end.The themes of man versus nature, man versus man, and the toll that leadership takes on the individual are examined without sentiment.  The U.S. Army invades Burma in World War II with iron-haired Jeff Chandler in the lead, followed by a strapping young Ty Hardin,Will Hutchins, Peter Brown, and Claude Akins.  The historical epic depicts the extraordinary efforts of the the 5307th Composite Unit to do what nobody else could do or did to prevent the Japanese Imperial Army from linking up with the German Army.  Typically, during World War II movies of the 1960s, the enemy--the Japanese here--were never shown close-up, but instead were only shown in long shots because they were our allies in 1962.  THE STEEL BAYONET director Sam Fuller, who later helmed THE BIG RED ONE, shows the grueling ordeal that 3000 volunteers went through slogging through jungles, wading through swamps, and climbing mountains. If the physical obstacles that these men conquered were not arduous enough, they also had to deal with cerebral malaria, amoebic dysentery, and/or scrub typhus. Promoted by Merrill from the rank of sergeant to lieutenant, Stockton (Ty Hardin of PT-109) hates writing leaders to the families of fallen ones as well as asking his troops to perform the impossible. Brigadier General Frank Merrill (Jeff Chandler) collapses urging his men to put one foot in front of the other to complete their mission.  Fuller does not treat combat as a game of heroes, and our heroes--though brave and gallant--are a weary, run-down bunch of men.  Only 100 survived this trek through Hades to defeat the Japanese.  John Hoyt makes a convincing General Stillwell.  Andrew Duggan plays the doctor who cannot believe that the troops can still fight.  One officer tells Merrill that he plans to have six kids after the war, line them up against a wall and tell them how tough Burma was and then beat the tar out of them if they do not cry.  Sadly, MERRILLS MARAUDERS was the last movie that Jeff Chandler made in a career cut short.  Milton Sperling of BATTLE OF THE BULGE co-scripted this opus with director Fuller from the 1956 non-fiction book by Charlton Ogburn Jr., entitled THE MARAUDERS. Interestingly, Ogburn served as a communications officer for the marauders. This Warner Brothers film was lensed on location in the Philippines,

**1/2 (out of four)

Pretty good war film with Jeff Chandler as a leader of a group soldiers who are trying to build the Burma Road while fighting the Japanese during World War II.

Post-war propaganda of the highest order. A zealous Hollywood tribute to the courage and tenacity of the allied infantry in Burma near the end of WWII. Though not in the same league with classics like Objective, Burma!, Merrill's Marauders surely inspired more than a few enlistments when it was released in March of 1962.
Another great WW2 picture from Sam Fuller. It's not better than FIXED BAYONETS, which is probably his best war movie, but it delivers the goods.
Another solid war film from Fuller. It's not quite as good as The Big Red One or his Korean war films, but it's nicely shot and typically (for Fuller that is) grim at times.
